title: Compute the \(AIC\) based on \(SSE\) — aic
text: Compute \(AIC\) based \(SSE\)

title: Compute the \(AIC\) based on \(SSE\) — aic
code: aic(fitobj)

title: Compute the \(AIC\) based on \(SSE\) — aic
text: fitobj Output fit function.

title: Compute the \(AIC\) based on \(SSE\) — aic
text: Numeric denoting \(AIC\)

title: Compute the \(AIC\) based on \(SSE\) — aic
code: # Generate a dataset data <- dataset(Y = rnorm(100), X = rnorm(100)) |>   suppressWarnings()  # Estimate the exponential discounting model on these data fitobj <- fit(   exponential(),   data,   itermax = 50,   trace = FALSE )  # Compute the AIC based on this fitobj aic(fitobj) #> [1] 12.32387

title: Compute the autocorrelation of the residuals — autocorrelation
text: fitobj Output fit function. lag lag autocorrelation compute. Defaults 1.

title: Compute the autocorrelation of the residuals — autocorrelation
text: Numeric denoting autocorrelation residuals. multiple dimensions exist residuals, autocorrelation computed dimension separately mean returned.

title: Compute the autocorrelation of the residuals — autocorrelation
code: # Generate a dataset data <- dataset(Y = rnorm(100), X = rnorm(100)) |>   suppressWarnings()  # Estimate the exponential discounting model on these data fitobj <- fit(   exponential(),   data,   itermax = 50,   trace = FALSE )  # Compute the autocorrelation based on this fitobj autocorrelation(fitobj) #> [1] -0.1600752

code: # Generate a dataset data <- dataset(Y = rnorm(100), X = rnorm(100)) |>   suppressWarnings()  # Estimate the exponential discounting model on these data fitobj <- fit(   exponential(),   data,   itermax = 50,   trace = FALSE )  # Compute the autocorrelation based on this fitobj bias(fitobj) #> [1] -5.459092e-05

what: Count the number of parameters in the covariance matrix — count_covariance
title: Count the number of parameters in the covariance matrix — count_covariance
text: Count number parameters covariance matrix

title: Count the number of parameters in the covariance matrix — count_covariance
code: count_covariance(d, covariance = "symmetric")

title: Count the number of parameters in the covariance matrix — count_covariance
text: d Integer denoting dimensionality model. covariance Character denoting structure covariance matrix. Can either "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal) "isotropic" (diagonal). Defaults "symmetric".

title: Count the number of parameters in the covariance matrix — count_covariance
text: Integer denoting number parameters covariance matrix specified conditions.

title: Count the number of parameters in the covariance matrix — count_covariance
code: count_covariance(2, "symmetric") #> [1] 3 count_covariance(2, "isotropic") #> [1] 2

what: Count number of parameters for a model — count_parameters
title: Count number of parameters for a model — count_parameters
text: Count number parameters model

title: Count number of parameters for a model — count_parameters
code: count_parameters(model, ...)  # S4 method for class 'exponential' count_parameters(   model,   dynamics = "isotropic",   covariance = "symmetric",   parameters_only = FALSE )  # S4 method for class 'quasi_hyperbolic' count_parameters(   model,   dynamics = "isotropic",   covariance = "symmetric",   parameters_only = FALSE )  # S4 method for class 'double_exponential' count_parameters(   model,   dynamics = "isotropic",   covariance = "symmetric",   parameters_only = FALSE )

title: Count number of parameters for a model — count_parameters
text: model instance model-class ... Arguments passed methods. dynamics Character denoting structure dynamical matrices. Can either "anisotropic" (completely free), "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal), "isotropic" (diagonal). Note influences different parameters different models, namely \(\Gamma\) exponential discounting model, \(N\) \(K\) quasi-hyperbolic discounting model, \(\Gamma\) \(N\) double-exponential discounting model. Defaults "isotropic". covariance Character denoting structure covariance matrix. Can either "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal) "isotropic" (diagonal). Defaults "symmetric". parameters_only Logical denoting whether count number parameters de parameter slot model (TRUE), count number parameters covariance matrix well (FALSE). Defaults FALSE.

title: Count number of parameters for a model — count_parameters
text: Integer denoting number parameters model contains within current specifications.

title: Count number of parameters for a model — count_parameters
code: # Define a model with a particular dimensionality my_model <- exponential(   parameters = list(     "alpha" = numeric(2),     "beta" = matrix(0, nrow = 2, ncol = 5),     "gamma" = matrix(0, nrow = 2, ncol = 2)   ),   covariance = matrix(0, nrow = 2, ncol = 2) )  # Get the number of parameters for this model under no restrictions (i.e.,  # anisotropic forgetting factors and symmetric covariances) count_parameters(   my_model,    dynamics = "anisotropic",   covariance = "symmetric" ) #> [1] 19  # Get the number of parameters for this model in the most limited case  # (i.e., isotropic forgetting factors and covariances) count_parameters(   my_model,   dynamics = "isotropic",   covariance = "isotropic" ) #> [1] 16

title: Dataset Class — dataset-class
text: class contains standard format dataset used within project, ensuring standardized approach computations.

title: Dataset Class — dataset-class
text: Y Numeric matrix observations fitted, dependent variables X Numeric matrix stimuli related Y, independent variables N Integer denoting number datapoints contained Y X. value automatically generated constructor dataset (see dataset).

title: Constructor for the dataset-class — dataset
text: Takes data.frame , based value arguments, constructs instance dataset-class. type class definition, ensured estimation, simulation, cross-validation, recovery routines can make use data structure, making definition easier within package. Note class defined within-subject level, meaning data provided constructor level.

title: Constructor for the dataset-class — dataset
code: dataset(   data = NULL,   y_cols = NULL,   x_cols = NULL,   Y = NULL,   X = NULL,   sorting_variable = NULL )

title: Constructor for the dataset-class — dataset
text: data data.frame containing dependent independent variables interest single person. Defaults NULL, case empty instance dataset-class created. y_cols character vector denoting names columns dependent variables. Defaults NULL, case error thrown asking information. x_cols character vector denoting names columns independent variables. Defaults NULL, case error thrown asking information. Y Numeric vector numeric matrix containing values dependent variable(s). Defaults NULL, case become empty matrix length \(N x 1\). Ignored data specified instead. X Numeric vector numeric matrix containing values independent variable(s). Defaults NULL, case data specified instead. sorting_variable Character denoting columnn name variable data according values Y X sorted. Defaults NULL, meaning sorting happen.

title: Constructor for the dataset-class — dataset
text: Instance dataset-class.

title: Constructor for the dataset-class — dataset
code: # Create a data.frame for reference my_data <- data.frame(   DV_1 = rep(1, each = 10),   DV_2 = rep(2, each = 10),   IV_1 = rep(3, each = 10),   IV_2 = rep(4, each = 10),   IV_3 = rep(5, each = 10) )  # Create a dataset with only a single DV and IV dataset(   data = my_data,    y_cols = "DV_1",   x_cols = "IV_1" ) #> An object of class "dataset" #>  #> Slot "Y": 10x1matrix #>      DV_1 #> [1,]    1 #> [2,]    1 #> [3,]    1 #> [4,]    1 #> [5,]    1 #> [6,]    1 #>  #> Slot "X": 10x1matrix #>      IV_1 #> [1,]    3 #> [2,]    3 #> [3,]    3 #> [4,]    3 #> [5,]    3 #> [6,]    3  # Create a dataset with multiple DV and IV dataset(   data = my_data,   y_cols = c("DV_1", "DV_2"),   x_cols = c("IV_1", "IV_2", "IV_3") ) #> An object of class "dataset" #>  #> Slot "Y": 10x2matrix #>      DV_1 DV_2 #> [1,]    1    2 #> [2,]    1    2 #> [3,]    1    2 #> [4,]    1    2 #> [5,]    1    2 #> [6,]    1    2 #>  #> Slot "X": 10x3matrix #>      IV_1 IV_2 IV_3 #> [1,]    3    4    5 #> [2,]    3    4    5 #> [3,]    3    4    5 #> [4,]    3    4    5 #> [5,]    3    4    5 #> [6,]    3    4    5

title: discounting: Discounting of Affect — discounting-package
text: Functions created aid large-scale evaluation discounting models capturing affect experimental daily-life datasets. Introduces class separate model well class datasets, making every function internal package run within standardized framework

title: Double-exponential Class — double_exponential-class
text: Class double-exponential discounting model. Follows similar structure model-class.

title: Double-exponential Class — double_exponential-class
text: d Integer denoting number dimensions model k Integer denoting number independent variables n Integer denoting number parameters parameters List containing parameters relevant particular model instance covariance Numeric matrix denoting residual covariance model

title: Constructor for the double_exponential-class — double_exponential
text: Defines instance double_exponential-class, class defining double-exponential discounting model. mathematical equations specify constructor, users can look details. information model , see vignette model definitions.

title: Constructor for the double_exponential-class — double_exponential
code: double_exponential(   d = NA,   k = NA,   parameters = NULL,   covariance = NULL,   cholesky = FALSE )

title: Constructor for the double_exponential-class — double_exponential
text: d Integer denoting number dimensions model. Defaults NA, case dimensionality inferred parameters. Note d k defined parameters left unspecified, model automatically create empty model specified dimensionality. k Integer denoting number independent variables. Defaults NA, case dimensionality inferred parameters. parameters List containing parameters relevant particular model instance. Defaults NULL, creating empty model \(d = 1\) \(k = 1\) (unless d k specified). covariance Numeric matrix denoting residual covariance model. Default NULL, creating matrix 0s dimensionality implied d. cholesky Logical denoting whether covariance lower-triangular decomposition matrix instead actual covariance matrix. Defaults FALSE.

title: Constructor for the double_exponential-class — double_exponential
text: Instance double_exponential-class

title: Constructor for the double_exponential-class — double_exponential
text: double-exponential discounting model assumes effect stimuli affect fades away exponential rate constructed two processes, one representing longer slower discounting rates, process' effect accounted weighted sum. model can defined : $$\boldsymbol{y}_t = \boldsymbol{\alpha} + \sum_{j = 0}^t \left( \omega \Gamma^j + (1 - \omega) N^j \right) B \boldsymbol{x}_{t - j} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}_t$$ \(\boldsymbol{\alpha}\) \(d\)-dimensional vector representing mean process \(\boldsymbol{y}\), \(\Gamma\) \(N\) \(d \times d\) matrices containing forgetting factors, determining long effect independent variables \(\boldsymbol{x}\) process \(\boldsymbol{y}\) lingers therefore determining dynamics system, \(\omega \[0, 0.5]\) determines strength \(\Gamma\) \(N\) influence discounting process, \(B\) \(d \times k\)matrix containing slopes independent variables \(\boldsymbol{x}\), \(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\) represents residuals system. Within package, assume : $$\boldsymbol{\epsilon} \overset{iid}{\sim} N(\boldsymbol{0}, \Sigma)$$ \(\Sigma\) \(d \times d\) matrix representing residual covariance matrix. define model, one minimally define parameters model parameters covariance. covariance, one either provides \(d \times d\) residual covariance matrix \(\Sigma\) (cholesky = FALSE) lower-triangular \(d \times d\) matrix \(G\) represents part decomposition matrix (cholesky = TRUE), can retrieve covariance matrix : $$\Sigma = G G^T$$ latter option ensures covariance matrix \(\Sigma\) defined within model positive-definite, may require additional thinking side user. parameters, one provide named list instances "alpha", "beta", "omega", "gamma", "nu", defining respective parameters \(\boldsymbol{\alpha}\), \(B\), \(\omega\), \(\Gamma\) \(N\) model. Note dimensionalities parameters match actively checked constructing class. important restrictions take account defining model: eigenvalues \(\lambda_i\) \(\Gamma\) \(N\)         lie 0 1, \(\lambda_i \[0, 1)\), restriction         imposes exponential decay rather sawtooth complex         dynamics weight \(\omega\) lie 0 0.5,         \(\omega \[0, 0.5]\), restriction imposed ensure         recoverability model covariance matrix \(\Sigma\) positive definite,         explained

title: Constructor for the double_exponential-class — double_exponential
code: double_exponential(   d = 2,   k = 2,   parameters = list(     "alpha" = numeric(2),     "beta" = diag(2) * 2,     "omega" = 0.25,     "gamma" = diag(2) * 0.75,     "nu" = diag(2) * 0.5   ),   covariance = diag(2) ) #> Model of class "double_exponential": #>  #> Dimension: 2 #> Number of predictors: 2 #> Number of parameters: 18 #>  #> Parameters: #>   alpha: |  0.00  | #>          |  0.00  | #>  #>   beta: | 2.00  0.00 | #>         | 0.00  2.00 | #>  #>   omega: |  0.25  | #>  #>   gamma: | 0.75  0.00 | #>          | 0.00  0.75 | #>  #>   nu: | 0.50  0.00 | #>       | 0.00  0.50 | #>  #>  #> Covariance: | 1.00  0.00 | #>             | 0.00  1.00 |  double_exponential(   d = 2,   k = 2 ) #> Model of class "double_exponential": #>  #> Dimension: 2 #> Number of predictors: 2 #> Number of parameters: 18 #>  #> Parameters: #>   alpha: |  0.00  | #>          |  0.00  | #>  #>   beta: | 0.00  0.00 | #>         | 0.00  0.00 | #>  #>   omega: |  0.00  | #>  #>   gamma: | 0.00  0.00 | #>          | 0.00  0.00 | #>  #>   nu: | 0.00  0.00 | #>       | 0.00  0.00 | #>  #>  #> Covariance: | 0.00  0.00 | #>             | 0.00  0.00 |

title: Exponential Class — exponential-class
text: Class exponential discounting model. Follows similar structure model-class.

title: Exponential Class — exponential-class
text: d Integer denoting number dimensions model k Integer denoting number independent variables n Integer denoting number parameters parameters List containing parameters relevant particular model instance covariance Numeric matrix denoting residual covariance model

title: Constructor for the exponential-class — exponential
text: Defines instance exponential-class, class defining exponential discounting model. mathematical equations specify constructor, users can look details. information model , see vignette model definitions.

title: Constructor for the exponential-class — exponential
code: exponential(   d = NA,   k = NA,   parameters = NULL,   covariance = NULL,   cholesky = FALSE )

title: Constructor for the exponential-class — exponential
text: d Integer denoting number dimensions model. Defaults NA, case dimensionality inferred parameters. Note d k defined parameters left unspecified, model automatically create empty model specified dimensionality. k Integer denoting number independent variables. Defaults NA, case dimensionality inferred parameters. parameters List containing parameters relevant particular model instance. Defaults NULL, creating empty model \(d = 1\) \(k = 1\) (unless d k specified). covariance Numeric matrix denoting residual covariance model. Default NULL, creating matrix 0s dimensionality implied d. cholesky Logical denoting whether covariance lower-triangular decomposition matrix instead actual covariance matrix. Defaults FALSE.

title: Constructor for the exponential-class — exponential
text: Instance exponential-class

title: Constructor for the exponential-class — exponential
text: exponential discounting model assumes effect stimuli affect fades away exponential rate can defined : $$\boldsymbol{y}_t = \boldsymbol{\alpha} + \sum_{j = 0}^t \Gamma^j B \boldsymbol{x}_{t - j} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}_t$$ \(\boldsymbol{\alpha}\) \(d\)-dimensional vector representing mean process \(\boldsymbol{y}\), \(\Gamma\) \(d \times d\) matrix containing forgetting factors, determining long effect independent variables \(\boldsymbol{x}\) process \(\boldsymbol{y}\) lingers therefore determining dynamics system, \(B\) \(d \times k\)matrix containing slopes independent variables \(\boldsymbol{x}\), \(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\) represents residuals system. Within package, assume : $$\boldsymbol{\epsilon} \overset{iid}{\sim} N(\boldsymbol{0}, \Sigma)$$ \(\Sigma\) \(d \times d\) matrix representing residual covariance matrix. exponential discounting model can also written instance \(VARMAX(1, 1)\), : $$\boldsymbol{y}_t = (I_d - \Gamma) \boldsymbol{\alpha} + B \boldsymbol{x}_t + \Gamma \boldsymbol{y}_{t - 1} - \Gamma \boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{t - 1} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}_t$$ \(I_d\) \(d \times d\) identity matrix. define model, one minimally define parameters model parameters covariance. covariance, one either provides \(d \times d\) residual covariance matrix \(\Sigma\) (cholesky = FALSE) lower-triangular \(d \times d\) matrix \(G\) represents part decomposition matrix (cholesky = TRUE), can retrieve covariance matrix : $$\Sigma = G G^T$$ latter option ensures covariance matrix \(\Sigma\) defined within model positive-definite, may require additional thinking side user. parameters, one provide named list instances "alpha", "beta", "gamma", defining respective parameters \(\boldsymbol{\alpha}\), \(B\), \(\Gamma\) model. Note dimensionalities parameters match actively checked constructing class. important restrictions take account defining model: eigenvalues \(\lambda_i\) \(\Gamma\) lie         0 1, \(\lambda_i \[0, 1)\), restriction         imposes exponential decay rather sawtooth complex         dynamics covariance matrix \(\Sigma\) positive definite,         explained

title: Constructor for the exponential-class — exponential
code: exponential(   d = 2,   k = 2,   parameters = list(     "alpha" = numeric(2),     "beta" = diag(2) * 2,     "gamma" = diag(2) * 0.5   ),   covariance = diag(2) ) #> Model of class "exponential": #>  #> Dimension: 2 #> Number of predictors: 2 #> Number of parameters: 13 #>  #> Parameters: #>   alpha: |  0.00  | #>          |  0.00  | #>  #>   beta: | 2.00  0.00 | #>         | 0.00  2.00 | #>  #>   gamma: | 0.50  0.00 | #>          | 0.00  0.50 | #>  #>  #> Covariance: | 1.00  0.00 | #>             | 0.00  1.00 |  exponential(   d = 2,   k = 2 ) #> Model of class "exponential": #>  #> Dimension: 2 #> Number of predictors: 2 #> Number of parameters: 13 #>  #> Parameters: #>   alpha: |  0.00  | #>          |  0.00  | #>  #>   beta: | 0.00  0.00 | #>         | 0.00  0.00 | #>  #>   gamma: | 0.00  0.00 | #>          | 0.00  0.00 | #>  #>  #> Covariance: | 0.00  0.00 | #>             | 0.00  0.00 |

title: Change model parameters — fill
text: Fill model parameters particular instance model-class ones provided numeric vector. Used objective_function allow predictions model cohering input typical numerical optimizers DEoptim nloptr provide within objective function.

title: Change model parameters — fill
code: fill(model, parameters, ...)  # S4 method for class 'exponential' fill(   model,   parameters,   dynamics = "isotropic",   covariance = "symmetric",   parameters_only = TRUE,   cholesky = TRUE )  # S4 method for class 'quasi_hyperbolic' fill(   model,   parameters,   dynamics = "isotropic",   covariance = "symmetric",   parameters_only = TRUE,   cholesky = TRUE )  # S4 method for class 'double_exponential' fill(   model,   parameters,   dynamics = "isotropic",   covariance = "symmetric",   parameters_only = TRUE,   cholesky = TRUE )

title: Change model parameters — fill
text: model Instance model-class parameters Numeric vector containing values parameters assigned model. Importantly, number parameters within vector correspond exactly number parameters needed model. Ideally, let functions internal package handle , rather defining parameters manually. ... Additional arguments passed methods. dynamics Character denoting structure dynamical matrices. Can either "anisotropic" (completely free), "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal), "isotropic" (diagonal). Note influences different parameters different models, namely \(\Gamma\) exponential discounting model, \(N\) \(K\) quasi-hyperbolic discounting model, \(\Gamma\) \(N\) double-exponential discounting model. Defaults "isotropic". covariance Character denoting structure covariance matrix. Can either "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal) "isotropic" (diagonal). Defaults "symmetric". parameters_only Logical denoting whether fill parameters de parameter slot model (TRUE), fill covariance matrix well (FALSE). Defaults TRUE. cholesky Logical denoting whether values covariance matrix taken values Cholesky decomposition instead. Defaults TRUE.

title: Change model parameters — fill
text: Instance model-class containing values parameters parameter-slot.

title: Change model parameters — fill
code: # Create an empty instance of the exponential discounting model my_model <- exponential()  # Assign the parameters of a vector to this exponential function fill(   my_model,   c(1, 2, 0.5) ) #> Model of class "exponential": #>  #> Dimension: 1 #> Number of predictors: 1 #> Number of parameters: 4 #>  #> Parameters: #>   alpha: |  1.00  | #>  #>   beta: | 2.00 | #>  #>   gamma: | 0.50 | #>  #>  #> Covariance: | 0.00 |

title: Fill the covariance matrix with values — fill_covariance
text: d Integer denoting dimensionality model. parameters Numeric vector containing values parameters assigned model. Importantly, number parameters within vector correspond exactly number parameters needed model. Ideally, let functions internal package handle , rather defining parameters manually. covariance Character denoting structure covariance matrix. Can either "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal) "isotropic" (diagonal). Defaults "symmetric". cholesky Logical denoting whether values covariance matrix taken values Cholesky decomposition instead. Defaults TRUE.

title: Fill the covariance matrix with values — fill_covariance
text: Matrix filled specified values.

title: Fill the covariance matrix with values — fill_covariance
code: fill_covariance(   2,   1:3,   covariance = "symmetric",   cholesky = FALSE ) #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    1    2 #> [2,]    2    3  fill_covariance(   2,   1:2,   covariance = "isotropic",   cholesky = FALSE ) #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    1    0 #> [2,]    0    2

what: Fit a model to data — fit
title: Fit a model to data — fit
text: method enables user fit model (defined model) particular dataset (defined data). estimation procedure makes use numerical optimization using either DEoptim nloptr, specified user. Estimation proceeds optimization according output objective function provided model, defined objective_function, thus using least-squares optimization standard.

title: Fit a model to data — fit
code: fit(model, data, ...)  # S4 method for class 'model,dataset' fit(   model,   data,   dynamics = "isotropic",   covariance = "symmetric",   optimizer = "DEoptim",   ... )

title: Fit a model to data — fit
text: model Instance model-class, defining model evaluate objective function . data Instance dataset-class containing data fit model . ... Arguments passed control parameters optimizer, either DEoptim.control opts argument nloptr. dynamics Character denoting structure dynamical matrices. Can either "anisotropic" (completely free), "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal), "isotropic" (diagonal). Note influences different parameters different models, namely \(\Gamma\) exponential discounting model, \(N\) \(K\) quasi-hyperbolic discounting model, \(\Gamma\) \(N\) double-exponential discounting model. Defaults "isotropic". covariance Character denoting structure covariance matrix. Can either "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal) "isotropic" (diagonal). Defaults "symmetric". optimizer Character denoting optimizer use estimation. Can either "DEoptim" differential evolution algorithm DEoptim "nloptr" library implemented nloptr. Defaults "DEoptim".

title: Fit a model to data — fit
text: named list containing instance model-class estimated parameters ("model"), results optimization procedure ("fit"), value objective ending optimization procedure ("objective"), residuals model ("residuals"), named vector containing values estimated parameters linked character vector explaining content ("parameters").

title: Fit a model to data — fit
text: Note currently, least-squares estimation assumed, meaning covariance matrix left objective function. maximum-likelihood needed instead, function need change.

title: Fit a model to data — fit
Generate model parameters — generate_parameters
text: Generation model parameters within function always occurs according uniform distribution within bounds defined models.

code: generate_parameters(model, ...)  # S4 method for class 'model' generate_parameters(model, ...)

title: Generate model parameters — generate_parameters
text: model Instance model-class ... Additional arguments passed get_bounds

title: Generate model parameters — generate_parameters
text: Numeric vector parameters model.

what: Get bounds of the parameters of a model — get_bounds
title: Get bounds of the parameters of a model — get_bounds
text: Get bounds parameters model

title: Get bounds of the parameters of a model — get_bounds
code: get_bounds(model, ...)  # S4 method for class 'exponential' get_bounds(   model,   dynamics = "isotropic",   covariance = "symmetric",   parameters_only = TRUE,   lower = NULL,   upper = NULL )  # S4 method for class 'quasi_hyperbolic' get_bounds(   model,   dynamics = "isotropic",   covariance = "symmetric",   parameters_only = TRUE,   lower = NULL,   upper = NULL )  # S4 method for class 'double_exponential' get_bounds(   model,   dynamics = "isotropic",   covariance = "symmetric",   parameters_only = TRUE,   lower = NULL,   upper = NULL )

title: Get bounds of the parameters of a model — get_bounds
text: model Instance model-class. ... Additional arguments passed methods. dynamics Character denoting structure dynamical matrices. Can either "anisotropic" (completely free), "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal), "isotropic" (diagonal). Note influences different parameters different models, namely \(\Gamma\) exponential discounting model, \(N\) \(K\) quasi-hyperbolic discounting model, \(\Gamma\) \(N\) double-exponential discounting model. Defaults "isotropic". covariance Character denoting structure covariance matrix. Can either "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal) "isotropic" (diagonal). Defaults "symmetric". parameters_only Logical denoting whether get bounds parameters de parameter slot model (TRUE), fill covariance matrix well (FALSE). Defaults TRUE. lower Numeric vector length substantive parameters model, denoting lower bounds one. exponential discounting model, example, value `c(0, 0, 0, 0)` denote minimal value 0 values \(\bm{\alpha}\), \(B\), \(\Gamma\), \(\Sigma\). Defaults depend model chosen accounting natural bounds data used project. Note parameters_only = TRUE, need specify bound covariances. upper Numeric vector functions lower, specifying upper bounds instead.

title: Get bounds of the parameters of a model — get_bounds
text: Named list containing numeric vectors denoting lower upper bounds parameters ("lower" "upper" resp.). order maintained

title: Get bounds of the parameters of a model — get_bounds
code: # Create an empty instance of the exponential discounting model my_model <- exponential()  # Get the bounds for the model get_bounds(   my_model,   dynamics = "anisotropic",   covariance = "isotropic",   parameters_only = FALSE ) #> $lower #> [1] -1e+00 -5e+00  0e+00  1e-05 #>  #> $upper #> [1] 1 5 1 1 #>   # Get the bounds for the model when specifying your personal lower and upper # bounds get_bounds(   my_model,   dynamics = "anisotropic",   covariance = "isotropic",   parameters_only = FALSE,   lower = c(0, -100, 0, 0.01),   upper = c(1, 100, 0.5, 1) ) #> $lower #> [1]  0e+00 -1e+02  0e+00  1e-02 #>  #> $upper #> [1]   1.0 100.0   0.5   1.0 #>

title: Get bounds for the parameters in the covariance matrix — get_bounds_covariance
text: d Integer denoting dimensionality model. lower, upper Numeric value containing value lower upper bounds covariance matrix. covariance Character denoting structure covariance matrix. Can either "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal) "isotropic" (diagonal). Defaults "symmetric".

title: Get bounds for the parameters in the covariance matrix — get_bounds_covariance
text: List containing two numeric vectors lower upper bounds covariance matrix order.

title: Get bounds for the parameters in the covariance matrix — get_bounds_covariance
code: get_bounds_covariance(   2,    0,   1,   covariance = "symmetric" ) #> [[1]] #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] 1 1 1 #>   get_bounds_covariance(   2,   0,    1,   covariance = "isotropic" ) #> [[1]] #> [1] 0 0 #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] 1 1 #>

title: Objective function — objective_function
text: method defines objective function estimation procedure looks like. result objective function sum squared error, meaning estimation routine makes use least-squares procedure.

title: Objective function — objective_function
code: objective_function(model, data, parameters, ...)  # S4 method for class 'model,dataset' objective_function(model, data, parameters, dynamics = "isotropic")

title: Objective function — objective_function
text: model Instance model-class, defining model evaluate objective function . data Instance dataset-class containing data fit model . parameters Numeric vector containing parameters model compute \(SSE\) . ... Additional arguments passed methods. dynamics Character denoting structure dynamical matrices. Can either "anisotropic" (completely free), "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal), "isotropic" (diagonal). Note influences different parameters different models, namely \(\Gamma\) exponential discounting model, \(N\) \(K\) quasi-hyperbolic discounting model, \(\Gamma\) \(N\) double-exponential discounting model. Defaults "isotropic".

title: Objective function — objective_function
text: sum squared error \(SSE\), quantifying misfit model data.

title: Objective function — objective_function
text: purposes package, objective function defines estimation routine go , therefore defining procedure fit model data particular set parameters evaluated. Within package, use least-squares procedure, therefore minimizing sum squared error (\(SSE\)), defined : $$SSE = Y - \hat{Y}$$ \(Y\) represents observed data \(\hat{Y}\) predictions model proposed parameter set. procedure used relies heavily implementation predict method get predictions \(\hat{Y}\). recovery go well, may useful take look method defined particular model. Note objective function useful using non-analytic approach estimation, one used package.

title: Objective function — objective_function
code: # Simulate data to use for this example data <- simulate(   quasi_hyperbolic(     parameters = list(       "alpha" = 1,        "beta" = as.matrix(2),       "nu" = as.matrix(0.75),       "kappa" = as.matrix(0.5)     ),     covariance = as.matrix(1)   ),   X = rnorm(100) )  # Evaluate the objective function for an exponential model with a particular # set of parameters objective_function(   exponential(),   data,   c(1, 2, 0.75) ) #> [1] 202.9634  # Evaluate the objective function when using exactly the model and the  # parameters that generated the data objective_function(   quasi_hyperbolic(),   data,   c(1, 2, 0.75, 0.5) ) #> [1] 113.6952

title: Name the relevant parameters of the model — parameter_names
text: model Instance model-class. ... Additional arguments passed methods. dynamics Character denoting structure dynamical matrices. Can either "anisotropic" (completely free), "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal), "isotropic" (diagonal). Note influences different parameters different models, namely \(\Gamma\) exponential discounting model, \(N\) \(K\) quasi-hyperbolic discounting model, \(\Gamma\) \(N\) double-exponential discounting model. Defaults "isotropic". covariance Character denoting structure covariance matrix. Can either "symmetric" (symmetric around diagonal) "isotropic" (diagonal). Defaults "symmetric". parameters_only Logical denoting whether name parameters de parameter slot model (TRUE), fill covariance matrix well (FALSE). Defaults TRUE.

title: Compute the model expectations — predict,exponential-method
text: object Instance model-class data Instance dataset-class

title: Compute the model expectations — predict,exponential-method
text: Instance dataset-class slot y contains predictions model

title: Compute the model expectations — predict,exponential-method
code: # Create an exponential discounting model my_model <- exponential(   parameters = list(     "alpha" = 0,     "beta" = 1,     "gamma" = 0.5   ),   covariance = 1 ) #> Warning: The parameter "gamma" should be a matrix: Changing type. #> Warning: The parameter "beta" should be a matrix: Changing type assuming a single independent variable. #> Warning: The argument "covariance" should be a matrix: Changing type.  # Create an instance of the dataset with only predictor values. It will throw # a warning because Y is implied to be empty, but we capture this warning  # with suppressWarnings() data <- dataset(   X = matrix(     rnorm(10),     nrow = 10,     ncol = 1   ) ) |>   suppressWarnings()  # Compute the values of Y as expected by the exponential discounting model  # defined in my_model predict(   my_model,   data ) #> An object of class "dataset" #>  #> Slot "Y": 10x1matrix #>            [,1] #> [1,] -1.1888899 #> [2,]  0.4886215 #> [3,] -0.7299649 #> [4,] -0.2920211 #> [5,] -0.2047085 #> [6,]  0.3256774 #>  #> Slot "X": 10x1matrix #>             [,1] #> [1,] -1.18888994 #> [2,]  1.08306647 #> [3,] -0.97427561 #> [4,]  0.07296130 #> [5,] -0.05869794 #> [6,]  0.42803165

title: Constructor for the quasi_hyperbolic-class — quasi_hyperbolic
text: d Integer denoting number dimensions model. Defaults NA, case dimensionality inferred parameters. Note d k defined parameters left unspecified, model automatically create empty model specified dimensionality. k Integer denoting number independent variables. Defaults NA, case dimensionality inferred parameters. parameters List containing parameters relevant particular model instance. Defaults NULL, creating empty model \(d = 1\) \(k = 1\) (unless d k specified). covariance Numeric matrix denoting residual covariance model. Default NULL, creating matrix 0s dimensionality implied d. cholesky Logical denoting whether covariance lower-triangular decomposition matrix instead actual covariance matrix. Defaults FALSE.

title: Constructor for the quasi_hyperbolic-class — quasi_hyperbolic
text: Instance quasi_hyperbolic-class

title: Constructor for the quasi_hyperbolic-class — quasi_hyperbolic
text: quasi-hyperbolic discounting model assumes effect stimuli affect fades away quasi-hyperbolic rate, first decreasing certain proportion first iteration decreasing exponential rate. model can defined : $$\boldsymbol{y}_t = \boldsymbol{\alpha} + \sum_{j = 0}^t N^j K^(j) B \boldsymbol{x}_{t - j} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}_t$$ \(\) indicator function \(0\) \(j = 0\) \(1\) otherwise, \(\boldsymbol{\alpha}\) \(d\)-dimensional vector representing mean process \(\boldsymbol{y}\), \(N\) \(K\) \(d \times d\) matrices containing forgetting factors, determining long effect independent variables \(\boldsymbol{x}\) process \(\boldsymbol{y}\) lingers therefore determining dynamics system, \(B\) \(d \times k\)matrix containing slopes independent variables \(\boldsymbol{x}\), \(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\) represents residuals system. Within package, assume : $$\boldsymbol{\epsilon} \overset{iid}{\sim} N(\boldsymbol{0}, \Sigma)$$ \(\Sigma\) \(d \times d\) matrix representing residual covariance matrix. quasi-hyperbolic discounting model can also written instance \(VARMAX(1, 1)\), : $$\boldsymbol{y}_t = (I_d - N) \boldsymbol{\alpha} + B \boldsymbol{x}_t N (K - I_d) B \boldsymbol{x}_{t - 1} + N \boldsymbol{y}_{t - 1} - N \boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{t - 1} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}_t$$ \(I_d\) \(d \times d\) identity matrix. Interestingly, multiple dimensions (\(d > 1\)), alternative definition quasi-hyperbolic discounting model, specifically one matrices \(N\) \(K\) flipped, : $$\boldsymbol{y}_t = \boldsymbol{\alpha} + \sum_{j = 0}^t \K^(j) N^j B \boldsymbol{x}_{t - j} + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}_t$$ \(VARMAX(1, 1)\) representation becomes: <> simplicity, use first definition quasi-hyperbolic model within package. define model, one minimally define parameters model parameters covariance. covariance, one either provides \(d \times d\) residual covariance matrix \(\Sigma\) (cholesky = FALSE) lower-triangular \(d \times d\) matrix \(G\) represents part decomposition matrix (cholesky = TRUE), can retrieve covariance matrix : $$\Sigma = G G^T$$ latter option ensures covariance matrix \(\Sigma\) defined within model positive-definite, may require additional thinking side user. parameters, one provide named list instances "alpha", "beta", "nu", "kappa", defining respective parameters \(\boldsymbol{\alpha}\), \(B\), \(N\) \(K\) model. Note dimensionalities parameters match actively checked constructing class. important restrictions take account defining model: eigenvalues \(\lambda_i\) \(N\) \(K\)         lie 0 1, \(\lambda_i \[0, 1)\), restriction         imposes exponential decay rather sawtooth complex         dynamics covariance matrix \(\Sigma\) positive definite,         explained

title: Constructor for the quasi_hyperbolic-class — quasi_hyperbolic
code: quasi_hyperbolic(   d = 2,   k = 2,   parameters = list(     "alpha" = numeric(2),     "beta" = diag(2) * 2,     "nu" = diag(2) * 0.5,     "kappa" = diag(2) * 0.75   ),   covariance = diag(2) ) #> Model of class "quasi_hyperbolic": #>  #> Dimension: 2 #> Number of predictors: 2 #> Number of parameters: 17 #>  #> Parameters: #>   alpha: |  0.00  | #>          |  0.00  | #>  #>   beta: | 2.00  0.00 | #>         | 0.00  2.00 | #>  #>   nu: | 0.50  0.00 | #>       | 0.00  0.50 | #>  #>   kappa: | 0.75  0.00 | #>          | 0.00  0.75 | #>  #>  #> Covariance: | 1.00  0.00 | #>             | 0.00  1.00 |  quasi_hyperbolic(   d = 2,   k = 2 ) #> Model of class "quasi_hyperbolic": #>  #> Dimension: 2 #> Number of predictors: 2 #> Number of parameters: 17 #>  #> Parameters: #>   alpha: |  0.00  | #>          |  0.00  | #>  #>   beta: | 0.00  0.00 | #>         | 0.00  0.00 | #>  #>   nu: | 0.00  0.00 | #>       | 0.00  0.00 | #>  #>   kappa: | 0.00  0.00 | #>          | 0.00  0.00 | #>  #>  #> Covariance: | 0.00  0.00 | #>             | 0.00  0.00 |

text: function takes one two models dimensionality simulates data first estimates second model data. allows users perform recovery studies – topic find accurately parameters model can estimated – perform distinguishability studies – topic find well can distinguish one model based fit statistics.

title: Simulate and estimate a model — recovery
code: recovery(sim_model, ...)  # S4 method for class 'model' recovery(   sim_model,   fit_model = NULL,   iterations = 100,   fx = list(),   X = NULL,   Xfun = NULL,   N = NULL,   dynamics = "isotropic",   covariance = "symmetric",   sim_dynamics = dynamics,   sim_covariance = covariance,   fit_dynamics = dynamics,   fit_covariance = covariance,   print_iteration = TRUE,   print_content = "",   ... )

title: Simulate and estimate a model — recovery
text: sim_model instance model-class data generated/simulated. Note model can empty: Parameters simulated automatically within function. ... Arguments passed fit. fit_model instance model-class estimated simulated data. Note model can empty, dimensionality (, d k) sim_model. default, fit_model equal sim_model iterations Integer denoting number iterations run recovery/distinguishability study. Defaults 100. fx Named list functions take output estimation procedure summarize way. function take single argument, output offit, return single value. Examples functions may useful include estimates \(AIC\) \(BIC\). Defaults empty list. X Numeric vector numeric matrix containing values predictor variable(s). numeric vector, dimension k predictor variables within object equal 1. numeric matrix, dimension k predictor variables within object equal number columns provided argument. length provided vector number rows provided matrix determine number simulated datapoints. Defaults NULL. provided, overrides value Xfun. Xfun Function list functions define values predictor variable(s) generated. functions take single argument N defining number values generated predictor variable, hence number datapoints generated simulation. list, result function list bound together matrix. Defaults NULL. N Number datapoints simulate. Passed Xfun defined. Defaults NULL. dynamics, sim_dynamics, fit_dynamics Character denoting structure dynamic parameters models. See fill guidance potential values. default, simulation fitting model "isotropic". covariance, sim_covariance, fit_covariance Character denoting structure covariance matrix models. See fill guidance potential values. default, simulation fitting model "symmetric". print_iteration Logical denoting whether print iteration recovery moment. Defaults TRUE. print_content Character containing information wish print alongside iteration. Gets printed iteration . Defaults empty string.
